case_name: Sardar Kapur Singh v. Government of East Punjab

facts.text: Sardar Kapur Singh was admitted to the Indian Civil Service upon the result of a competitive examination held at Delhi in 1931.

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Kapur Singh  who will hereinafter be referred to as the appellant  was admitted by the Secretary of State for India in Council to the Indian Civil Service upon the result of a companypetitive examination held at Delhi in 1931.

facts.text: The appellant returned to India in November 1933 and was posted as Assistant Commissioner, Ferozepore in the Province of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: After a period of training in the United Kingdom, the appellant returned to India in November, 1933 and was posted as Assistant Commissioner, Ferozepore in the Province of Punjab.

facts.text: He served in the Province in various capacities between the years 1933 and 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He served in the Province in various capacities between the years 1933 and 1947.

facts.text: In July 1947, he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Dharamsala and continued to hold that office till February 11, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1947, he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Dharamsala and companytinued to hold that office till February 11, 1948,

facts.text: On February 11, 1948, he was transferred to Hoshiarpur and continued to hold the office of Deputy Commissioner till a few days before April 14, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: when he was transferred to Hoshiarpur at which place he companytinued to hold the office of Deputy Commissioner till a few days before April 14, 1949.

facts.text: On April 13, 1949, the appellant was served with an order passed by the Government of East Punjab suspending him from service.

anchor.surface_text: On April 13, 1949, the appellant was served with an order passed by the Government of East Punjab suspending him from service.

facts.text: On May 5, 1950, the appellant submitted a representation to the President of India protesting against the suspension.

anchor.surface_text: On May 5, 1950, the appellant submitted a representation to the President of India protesting against the action of the Government of East Punjab suspending him from service

facts.text: On May 18, 1950, the Government of East Punjab appointed Mr. Eric Weston, Chief Justice of the East Punjab High Court as Enquiry Commissioner under the Public Servants Inquiries Act, XXXVII of 1850, to hold an enquiry against the appellant on twelve articles of charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of East Punjab on May 18, 1950, appointed Mr. Eric Weston, Chief Justice of the East Punjab High Court as Enquiry Commissioner under the Public Servants  Inquiries  Act, XXXVII of 1850, to hold an enquiry against the appellant on twelve articles of charges.

facts.text: Notice was issued to the appellant of those charges.

anchor.surface_text: Notice was issued to the appellant of those charges.

facts.text: On November 5, 1950, at the suggestion of the Enquiry Commissioner, the Government of East Punjab withdrew charges Nos. 11 and 12 and the Enquiry Commissioner proceeded to hold the enquiry on the remaining ten charges.

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1950, at the suggestion of the Enquiry Commissioner, the Government of East Punjab with drew charges Nos. 11 and 12 and the Enquiry Commissioner proceeded to hold the enquiry on the remaining ten charges.

facts.text: Charges 1, 2, 7, 8, 9 and 10 related to misappropriation of diverse sums of money received by or entrusted to the appellant, for which he failed to account.

anchor.surface_text: Charges 1, 2, 7, 8, 9 and 10 related to misappropriation of diverse sums of money received by or entrusted to the appellant, for which he failed to account.

facts.text: Charges Nos. 1 to 4 and 7 to 10 related to the official conduct of the appellant when he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Dharamsala and charges Nos. 5 and 6 related to the period when he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Hoshiarpur.

anchor.surface_text: Charges Nos. 1 to 4 and 7 to 10 related to the official companyduct of the appellant when he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Dharamsala and charges Nos. 5 and 6 related to the period when he was posted as Deputy Commissioner at Hoshiarpur.

facts.text: The Enquiry Commissioner heard the evidence on behalf of the State at Dharamsala between July 31 and August 21, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Enquiry Commissioner heard the evidence on behalf of the State at Dharamsala between July 31 and August 21, 1950.

facts.text: Enquiry proceedings were resumed on September 5 at Simla and were continued till October 23 on which date the evidence on behalf of the State was closed.

anchor.surface_text: Enquiry proceedings were then resumed on September 5 at Simla and were companytinued till October 23 on which date the evidence on behalf of the State was closed.

facts.text: On October 27, the appellant filed a list of defence witnesses. A detailed written statement was filed by the appellant and he gave evidence on oath between November 28 and December 5.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, the appellant filed a list of defence witnesses. A detailed written statement was filed by the appellant and he gave evidence on oath between November 28 and December 5.

facts.text: The defence witnesses were then examined between December 5 and December 28. The appellant's case was treated closed on December 28, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The defence witnesses were then examined between December 5 and December 28. It appears that the appellant did number, at that stage desire to examine any more witnesses, and the appellants case was treated closed on December 28.

facts.text: On May 14, 1951, the Enquiry Commissioner prepared his report.

anchor.surface_text: On May 14, 1951, the Enquiry Commissioner prepared his report.

facts.text: The Enquiry Commissioner held that the appellant had received an aggregate amount of Rs. 16,734-11-6 and failed to account for it, proving misappropriation charges.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the appellant had taken the amount referred to in charge No. 1 from the Government... the appellant had received an aggregate amount of Rs. 16,734-11-6 and that even though he had made certain disbursements to refugees, the appellant had failed to account for the disbursement of the amount received by him

facts.text: On February 11, 1952, the Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs supplied a copy of the report to the appellant and informed of President's provisional decision to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1952, the Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs supplied a companyy of the report to the appellant and informed that on a careful companysideration of the report... the President accordingly provisionally decided that the appellant should be dismissed from Government service.

facts.text: The appellant submitted a detailed statement on May 7, 1952, which runs into 321 printed pages.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted a detailed statement on May 7, 1952, which runs into 321 printed pages of record.

facts.text: By order dated July 27, 1953, dismissed the appellant from service with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: and by order dated July 27, 1953, dismissed the appellant from service with immediate effect.

facts.text: The order passed by the President was challenged by a petition filed in the East Punjab High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the President was challenged by a petition filed in the East Punjab High Court for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: East Punjab High Court dismissed the petition by Chief Justice Bhandari and Mr. Justice Khosla.

anchor.surface_text: By separate, but companycurring judgments, Chief Justice Bhandari and Mr. Justice Khosla of the East Punjab High Court dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Against the order of dismissal of the petition, this appeal has been filed by the appellant pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of dismissal of the petition, this appeal has been filed by the appellant pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court.

arguments.claim: PSIA 1850 applies to members of Indian Civil Service as they are not removable without sanction of Government

anchor.surface_text: The submission of the appellant that the Act did not apply to enquiries against members of the Indian Civil Service is without force. The Act was, as the preamble recites, passed for regulating enquiries into the behavior of public servants who are not removable from appointment without the sanction of the Government.

holdings.text: The appellant was employed under the East Punjab Government and the State Government had authority under s.2 of the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 to direct an enquiry into charges against him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was, at the date when enquiry was directed, employed under the East Punjab Government and there is nothing in the Constitution which abrogates the authority of the State to direct an enquiry under s. 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant served as Deputy Commissioner under East Punjab; s.2 authorizes State for persons employed under it; Constitution does not abrogate this.

holdings.text: The Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 applies to members of the Indian Civil Service as they are not removable without sanction of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The submission of the appellant that the Act did not apply to enquiries against members of the Indian Civil Service is without force. The Act was, as the preamble recites, passed for regulating enquiries into the behavior of public servants who are not removable from appointment without the sanction of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble targets superior public servants not removable without Government sanction; ICS members hold during President's pleasure but employed under Union/State.

holdings.text: Enquiry under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 is valid for ICS members and does not require a separate enquiry under Rule 55 of Civil Services (Classification, Control & Appeal) Rules as Rule 55 is without prejudice to the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 55 of the Civil Services Classification, Control and Appeal Rules provides Without prejudice to the provisions of the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, no order of dismissal...

holdings.reasoning_summary: "Without prejudice" means alternative procedures; no mandate for dual enquiries; cites S.A. Venkataraman v. Union.

holdings.text: Holding an enquiry under the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 does not violate Article 14 as procedures under the Act and Rule 55 are substantially similar and no prejudice caused.

anchor.surface_text: Does the holding of an enquiry against a public servant under the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 violate the equal protection clause of the Constitution ? The appellant submits that the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both procedures afford reasonable opportunity per Art.311; differences not onerous or prejudicial; no discrimination in choosing one alternative.

holdings.text: The enquiry by the Enquiry Commissioner was not vitiated by violation of rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that the Enquiry Commissioner held the enquiry in a manner violative of the rules of natural justice, may not be considered. His Lordship, after considering the material furnished to support the plea, agreed with the view of the High Court that the enquiry was not vitiated

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant examined 82 witnesses, filed detailed defence; agreed with High Court after review of material; sufficient opportunities provided.

holdings.text: The President was not required to conduct a fresh viva voce examination of witnesses or grant oral hearing after fair enquiry by Commissioner; written representation suffices under Art.311.

anchor.surface_text: The President of India was not bound before passing an order dismissing the appellant, to hear the evidence of witnesses. He could arrive at his conclusion on the evidence already recorded in the enquiry by the Enquiry Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on recorded evidence post fair enquiry; cites High Commissioner v. I.M. Lall and Khem Chand v. Union; reasonable opportunity via written submission.

precedents.citation: S. A. Venkataraman v. The Union of India and Another 1954 S.C.R. 1150

anchor.surface_text: S. A. Venkataraman v. The Union of India and Another 1954 S.C.R. 1150 by Mr. Justice Mukherjea, in delivering the judgment of the court that Rule 55, which finds a place in the same chapter, lays down the procedure to be followed before passing an order of dismissal,

precedents.case_name: S. A. Venkataraman v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule 55 lays down the procedure to be followed before passing an order of dismissal, removal or reduction in rank against any member of the service and an enquiry can be held either under the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 or under the rule

precedents.citation: Khem Chand v. The Union of India and Others 1958 S.C.R. 1080 at 1096-97

anchor.surface_text: Khem Chand v. The Union of India and Others 1958 S.C.R. 1080 at 1096-97 . It was observed that the reasonable opportunity envisaged by the provision under consideration includes - An opportunity to deny his guilt and establish his innocence, which he can only do if he is told what the charges leveled against him are and the allegations on which such charges are based  b  an opportunity to defend himself by cross-examining the witnesses produced against him and by examining himself or any other witnesses in support of his defence and finally  c  an opportunity to make his representation as to why the proposed punishment should not be inflicted on him, which he can only do if the competent authority, after the enquiry is over and after applying his mind to the gravity or otherwise of the charges proved against the government servant tentatively proposes to inflict one of the three punishments and communicates the same to the government servant.

precedents.case_name: Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: The reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2) includes opportunity to deny guilt and establish innocence by being informed of charges, to defend by cross-examination and own evidence, and to represent against proposed punishment after tentative decision

precedents.citation: The High Commissioner for India and Another v. I. M. Lal 75 L.A. 225

anchor.surface_text: The High Commissioner for India and Another v. I. M. Lal 75 L.A. 225 dealing with s. 240, clause 3, Lord Thankerton in dealing with similar contentions observed In the opinion of their Lordships, no action is proposed within the meaning of the sub-section until a definite conclusion has been come to on the charges and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on. Prior to that stage, the charges are unproved and the suggested punishments are merely hypothetical. It is on that stage being reached that the statute gives the civil servant the opportunity for which sub-section (3) makes provision. Their Lordships would only add that they see no difficulty in the statutory opportunity being reasonably afforded at more than one stage. If the civil servant had been through an inquiry under rule 55, it would not be reasonable that he should ask for a repetition of that stage, if duly carried out but that would not exhaust his statutory right, and he would still be entitled to represent against the punishment proposed as the result of the findings of the inquiry.

precedents.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: No action is proposed until definite conclusion reached on charges and provisional punishment determined; statutory opportunity arises then and can be at multiple stages; no repetition of enquiry stage if already done under rule 55

precedents.citation: Khem Chand v. The Union of India and Others 1958 S.C.R. 1080 where at p. 1099

anchor.surface_text: Khem Chand v. The Union of India and Others 1958 S.C.R. 1080 where at p. 1099, it was observed by Chief Justice S. R. Das Of course if the government servant has been through the enquiry under r. 55, it would not be reasonable that he should ask for a repetition of that stage, if duly carried out.

precedents.case_name: Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: If government servant has gone through enquiry under r.55, it would not be reasonable to ask for repetition of that stage if duly carried out

anchor.surface_text: The submission of the appellant that the Act did not apply to enquiries against members of the Indian Civil Service is without force.
